questions.text: Autoimmune hepatitis is suspected in a woman presenting with fatigue, pruritus, and arthralgia. She has a past history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which of the following is not part of the simplified scoring system for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Presence of viral markers is not a part of the simplified scoring system for diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis.

The simplified scoring system includes four variables. They are:

  1. Autoantibodies
  2. Elevated serum IgG level
  3. Typical compatible histologic features
  4. Absence of viral hepatitis markers

The clinical presentation in autoimmune hepatitis is variable and shares features with acute and chronic hepatitis of other aetiologies. They usually present with an insidious onset of non-specific symptoms such as fatigue, anorexia and eventually jaundice. It can then progress to extensive liver necrosis and liver failure.

Autoimmune hepatitis is associated with several autoimmune diseases such as:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Thyroiditis and Grave's disease
  • Haemolytic anemia

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
questions.solution:
Minocycline is associated with the development of drug-induced AIH.

Other drugs associated with AIH include nitrofurantoin, methyldopa, diclofenac, and possibly statins.

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady is suspected to have autoimmune hepatitis. Which of the following antibodies is unlikely to be present in her serum?
questions.solution:
cANCA is not seen in autoimmune hepatitis. It is positive in Wegner's granulomatosis. pANCA is what is seen in autoimmune hepatitis.

There are 2 types of autoimmune hepatitis:

Type I (classic) autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in young women. It is linked to HLA-DR3 or HLA-DR4. It responds well to steroids and has a better prognosis. The autoantibodies that are seen in type I are:

  • ANA - antinuclear antibodies
  • ASMA - anti-smooth muscle actin
  • pANCA - perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic
  • anti-SLA - anti-soluble liver antigen

Type II autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in children. It is linked to HLA-DRB1 or HLA-DQB1. It usually leads to fibrosis, cirrhosis and liver failure. The autoantibodies that are seen in type II are:

  • Anti-LKM 1 - anti-liver kidney microsomes
  • Anti-liver cytosol 1

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presenting with abdominal pain is diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. The mainstay of management in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis is glucocorticoid therapy.

Glucocorticoids are started at high doses and tapered down to a low maintenance dose. The dose of glucocorticoids is often reduced by combining with azathioprine.

The benefits of glucocorticoid + azathioprine combination therapy are:

  • Reduction in the duration of therapy.
  • Avoid life-threatening complications of steroids (e.g., cushingoid features, hypertension, diabetes, osteoporosis).

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis did not respond well to glucocorticoids. Which among the following is false regarding her further management options?
questions.solution:
Liver transplant is not contraindicated in refractory autoimmune hepatitis even though the risk of recurrence is high.

The medical management of refractory autoimmune hepatitis include:

  • High dose glucocorticoids
  • Glucocorticoids + high dose azathioprine
  • Addition of cyclosporine, tacrolimus, or mycophenolate mofetil.

questions.text: A young lady has been on treatment for autoimmune hepatitis for 2 weeks, she has now come for follow-up investigations. Which of the following suggests a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Persistently increased serum bilirubin after 2 weeks of therapy suggests a poor prognosis.

Early signs of poor prognosis include:

  • Failure of serum bilirubin to reduce after 2 weeks of therapy.

Early signs of good prognosis include:

  • An increase in serum albumin.
  • A decrease in serum bilirubin, globulins and aminotransferases.
  • Improvement of symptoms.

Histopathologic improvement can often take months to years.

questions.text: The most common symptom of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is fatigue.

Primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is a granulomatous autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of interlobular hepatic bile ducts. 

Most patients with PBC are asymptomatic at the time of the diagnosis. Fatigue and pruritus are both common presenting symptoms. However, the most common symptom is fatigue.

Other symptoms and signs are -

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Hyperpigmentation 
  • Xanthomas and xanthelasma 
  • Jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis is now diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis. Which of the following is false regarding her lab values?
questions.solution:
Anti-LKM 2 antibodies are not seen in primary biliary cholangitis. They are seen in drug-induced hepatitis.

The laboratory findings of primary biliary cholangitis include :

  • Liver function tests
    • Elevated ALP 
    • Elevated GGT and 5'- nucleotidase
    • Elevated ALT and AST
  • Serology - 
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies - positive in 95% of patients. These are mostly directed against the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
    • Antinuclear antibodies
  • Elevated HDL, LDL, and VLDL
  • Elevated serum IgM

Hyperbilirubinemia is seen once cirrhosis has developed.

questions.text: A patient with a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis has been taking ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) twice daily. She now presents with ascites and variceal bleeding. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Add obeticholic acid to the treatment

questions.solution:
The presence of ascites and variceal bleeding suggest decompensated liver disease and the appropriate treatment is liver transplantation. 

The first-line drug in primary biliary cholangitis is ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA). It only slows the rate of progression of the disease. It does not provide any symptomatic benefit or cure the disease.

Obeticholic acid is another drug used in PBC as monotherapy or in combination with UDCA. It is a farnesoid X receptor agonist.

Liver transplantation is considered when there are signs of decompensation or portal hypertension such as ascites, variceal bleeding, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, or malnutrition.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with fatigue, pruritis, and xanthomas over the elbows. A biopsy of her bile duct revealed florid duct lesions. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Florid duct lesion is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). It is the lymphocytes and plasma cells all centered around bile ducts. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis has the characteristic  "onion-skin" concentric fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about primary sclerosing cholangitis is false?

choices.text: Affects both intra and extrahepatic bile ducts
Liver biopsy definitively establishes the diagnosis

questions.solution:
Liver biopsy does not establish the diagnosis in primary sclerosing cholangitis. The diagnosis requires imaging with MRCP. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic progressive disorder characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic biliary ducts resulting in strictures and cholestasis. The cause is unknown. Most patients have underlying ulcerative colitis. It has an association with HLA DRw52. Patients present with symptoms of cholestasis such as fatigue and pruritus. 

The laboratory findings include:

  • Liver function tests - Elevated ALP and aminotransferases.
  • Increased serum IgM levels
  • Positive p-ANCA

MRCP is the investigation of choice. It shows multiple strictures in intra and extrahepatic bile ducts. Liver biopsy reveals a concentric "onion skin" fibrosis. This is however not pathognomic of PSC. 

There is no definitive treatment. It involves the administration of UDCA and liver transplantation.

PSC can lead to the development of cholangiocarcinoma
